comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: Article from Wikipedia is here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Connecticut_(BB-18) although this photo has differences from the other photo of the Connecticut, the bow and tower structures, for example.

comment.author: 52603685@N00
comment._content: What was the purpose of those cage masts?  They seem to be tall enough to make a target out of the ship.

comment.author: 18213712@N07
comment._content:
No radar so lookouts had to be high to see other ships and where the shots landed for fire control.  Less wind hamper and visibility with the cages.
My opinion with no research.

comment.author: 18213712@N07
comment._content: Also more strength to hold up the platforms.

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: From the date, and the proximity to other photos, looks like this was part of the 1912 fleet review: www.geocities.com/scs028a/1912List.html Indeed though the cage masts look rather different than the towers in the other photos. However, this link: www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-c/bb18.htm suggests that she had her masts altered ca 1908/1909 which would have been in time for this picture.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: You can pinpoint this photo to 12:10 or 12:30 pm on Monday October 14, 1912, query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D02E4DD133CE6...
